body:
Summary: The SSEBop model is based on the Simplified Surface Energy Balance (SSEB) approach (Senay et al., 2007, 2011) with a unique parameterization for operational applications. It combines ET fractions, generated from Landsat Collection 1 Provisional Surface Temperature, with reference ET using a thermal index approach based on the principle of satellite psychrometry (Senay, 2018). The unique feature of the SSEBop parameterization is that it uses pre-defined and seasonally dynamic boundary conditions that are specific to each pixel for the “hot/dry” and “cold/wet” reference points. The Landsat Provisional Actual Evapotranspiration (ETa) science product is generated by calculating the latent heat flux based on surface energy balance principles using a robust model and can be fundamental in the understanding of the spatiotemporal dynamics of water use over land surfaces.

When citing: Landsat Provisional Actual Evapotranspiration Science Product courtesy of the U.S. Geological Survey.

Version Updates: The Landsat SSEBop ET remote sensing model is developed and versioned for two major framework implementations including: ESPA Level-3 Provisional Landsat Provisional Actual Evapotranspiration Version 1.0; and SSEBop-GEE Version 0.1.2. These are continuously updating frameworks focused on modeling and compute innovations using test-driven developments.

Requirements: SSEBop ESPA: On-Demand Interface at https://espa.cr.usgs.gov/
SSEBop-GEE: Python 3 install and supported dependencies including earthengine-api, gdal, numpy

Dependencies: Landsat Surface Temperature and auxiliary data are required for successful processing of the ETa product. The ETa auxiliary data include the temperature difference between hot/dry and cold/wet limits (dT), maximum daily air temperature (Ta) obtained from Daymet (https://daymet.ornl.gov), and alfalfa-reference ET (ETr) data retrieved from GridMET (http://www.climatologylab.org/gridmet.html/) (Abatzoglou, 2013). The auxiliary data for ETa calculation is already processed, so it is not a dominating factor in the ETa product generation latency.

Installation: SSEBop ESPA: On-Demand Interface at https://espa.cr.usgs.gov/
SSEBop-GEE: Internal users can install Python 3 and dependencies using pip/anaconda environments. Command line operation for supported platforms: Unix, Linux, Windows.

Assumptions: The actual ET (ETa) is based on the product of ET fraction (ETf) and a climatology (long term normal) reference ET (ETr). Because the ETr is a climatology and does not capture the day-to-day weather variability, comparison against flux tower data may produce relatively larger deviations on a given day, but this effect would be minimized when the ETa data are aggregated to larger time scales such as monthly. Users are encouraged to use the provided ETf with the best available ETr for the corresponding day for evaluating the performance of the model against daily flux towers or other independent datasets. However, the ETa data are expected to capture the spatial variability adequately.

Structure:
See Reference links.
The Actual ET algorithm generally involves the following steps: 
1. Build smoothed NDVI 
2. Read Surface Temperature data 
3. Read auxiliary data 
4. Calculate model calibration factor (C factor) 
5. Correct environmental lapse rate 
6. Calculate Thot 
7. Create ETf and ETa bands 
8. Create ET QA band 
9. Create percent uncertainty and ET uncertainty bands

Equations: Users can refer to algorithm information: https://www.usgs.gov/media/files/landsat-provisional-actual-evapotranspiration-add and at Senay, G.B. (2018): https://doi.org/10.13031/aea.12614

Temporal Information: The model is run on a daily time step for each Landsat overpass (mm/day). Temporally aggregated products can also be produced for monthly, seasonal, or annual time steps, depending on application. 1984-present.

Spatial Information: CONUS, Pixel-based Landsat thermal resolution (60-120 meters), GeoTIFF raster type. Model applications have included field-level, watershed, basins, states, nation-wide.

Limitations: See Caveats and Constraints: https://www.usgs.gov/land-resources/nli/landsat/landsat-provisional-actual-evapotranspiration

Input/Output and Variables: https://www.usgs.gov/media/files/landsat-provisional-actual-evapotranspiration-add

Functions: Gridded Air Temperature, Surface Temperature, Potential ET

Benchmarks: Eddy Covariance Flux Tower station data validation and Water Balance evaluation at the aggregate/subbasin level.

Usage: More than 3,688 ESPA Level-3 ET products ordered or downloaded in one month since its launch in June 2020. More than 500 manuscript citations for SSEBop. Data and applications include a wide array of water reporting, conservation, and management practices.

References:

Operational Evapotranspiration Mapping Using Remote Sensing and Weather Datasets: A New Parameterization for the SSEB Approach. Journal of the American Water Resources Association 49 (3): 577-591. https://doi.org/10.1111/jawr.12057

Senay, G., Friedrichs, M., Singh, R., & Velpuri, N. (2016).  Evaluating Landsat 8 evapotranspiration for water use mapping in the Colorado River Basin.  Remote Sensing of Environment 185: 171-185. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2015.12.043

Senay, G., Schauer, M., Friedrichs, M., Velpuri, N., Singh, R. (2017).  Satellite-based water use dynamics using historical Landsat data (1984–2014) in the southwestern United States.  Remote Sensing of Environment 202: 98-112. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rse.2017.05.005
